Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquistition of an Integrated Gas Exchange and Fluorescence Instrument for Multidisciplinary Physiological Research
Award.AbstractNarration:
An award is made to Grinnell College to support biology research and education with a major research instrument for diverse studies of physiology. The instrument, the LI-6400XT, will have an immediate impact on active research by faculty and their advanced undergraduate students, and it well help biology students in several courses learn by research, the most effective kind of science education. Grinnell College has a deep commitment to providing quality science education and research training to all students, including those traditionally underrepresented in the sciences. This instrument will support Grinnell's commitment, beginning with the incoming-student lab experiences of the nationally recognized Grinnell Science Project, and weaving through every level of our biology curriculum. This research instrument will enrich student learning, facilitating authentic research experiences that generate high-quality outcomes.

Representing the foremost technology available for real-time analysis of photosynthesis (i.e., carbon dioxide uptake) and respiration (i.e., carbon dioxide output), the LI-6400XT will find immediate use in research projects in plant physiology, plant ecology, fungal biology, and biogeochemistry. Portable, flexible, and allowing control of light, temperature, and humidity, the instrument enables measurements in a wide range of living systems and settings, from prokaryotes and fungi, to plants, animals, and soils; and from laboratories to remote field sites. The multiple functions of the LI-6400XT will provide new means to investigate significant questions about what controls: (1) plant acclimation to temperature stress; (2) plant adaptation to drought; (3) decomposition by prokaryotes and fungi in drylands; and (4) how the carbon cycle operates in river floodplains.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Grinnell College's long-term goal is to provide its faculty and undergraduate students with advanced and accessible research instrumentation. The College's goal in obtaining the LI-6800 system was to support faculty-student research and education in the Biology Department.  Our specific aims fell into two categories: (1) Use of the instrument for faculty-led research involving undergraduates to collect publication-quality data across a diverse range of biological sub-disciplines, and (2) to equip students with practical and authentic research experiences using this instrument across all levels of our inquiry-based undergraduate curriculum.

Representing the foremost technology available for the real-time analysis of photosynthesis and respiration, the LI-6800XT was used frequently in ongoing and multidisciplinary research projects in plant physiology, fungal biology, evolutionary ecology, and biogeochemistry. Its portability and flexible sample accommodation enabled measurements on a wide range of living systems and settings, from microbes and fungi, to plants, animals, and soils; and from growth chambers to remote field sites. The functionality of the LI-6800XT provided new means to investigating important questions about temperature-stress responses in plants, the evolution of plant drought adaptation, adaptive microbial traits in drylands, and the functioning of floodplain ecosystems.

Grinnell has pioneered teaching introductory and intermediate biology students through research, recognizing that model as the most effective approach to science education. Our pedagogy is in line with the most recent calls to action for education reform in biology, most recently by the American Association for the Advancement of Science in 2011 with its Vision and Change in Undergraduate Biology Education: A Call to Action.  Consequently, the instrument enjoyed widespread use at all levels of our curriculum.  Our innovative first-year course BIO-150: Introduction to Biological Inquiry, focuses on developing the skills and concepts associated with the process of science (not just facts), including the design and completion of independent projects.  In BIO-150, approximately 85 students received training in the basic operation of the instrument, and over two dozen used the instrument directly in their semi-independent student projects examining plant responses to stress (heat, changes in [CO2], salinity, drought, high light. In our mid-level course BIO-251: Molecules, Cells, and Organisms, the instrument turned abstract course concepts into hands-on demonstrations of photosynthesis and respiration processes in living organisms for more than 200 students.  At the advanced level, students in BIO-334: Plant Physiology used the instrument in weeks-long projects investigating the response of photosynthesis to environmental stress.  Several of these projects produced preliminary results that were then used to develop research opportunities for semester- or summer-long individually-mentored projects with undergraduates.

Having our students use an unfamiliar and complex instrument in the context of their coursework, helped them develop a sense of confidence that they are able to approach research problems by using new technologies. They become less afraid to explore new technologies and more adept at finding ways to incorporate new technologies into their future work, regardless of whether that work is biological in nature. As undergraduates who will become active members of society, the broader impacts of this project on the scientific literacy and environmental advocacy of our students has been a major outcome. We thank the NSF for providing the opportunity to add this wonderful instrument to our teaching and research infrastructure and look forward to its use for several years to come.
